advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE TEMPTATION...</strong></font><br><blockquote>Franklin dealer advert (1983)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SPANISH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1ST. U.S. ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Epson QX-10 advert appeared in January 1983. It took eight pages and explained the advantages of the Valdoc system, the benefits of the CP/M operating system compatibility, and the advanced hardware concepts. <br><br> In conclusion, it said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> <b>The most important component is you</b><br> You don't buy a computer for how "smart" it is. You buy one for how smart it makes you.<br> The Epson QX-10 was conceived, designed, engineered and built with just one thought in mind: to vastly expand your ability to see, to think, to create with a system that acts as a natural extension of the human mind.<br> The QX-10 is not a computer designed to play games, although it plays games as well as any and better than most.<br> It's a computer for people who think.<br> And who want to think better.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANCO BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"> Our Peripheral Expansion System gives you plug-in cards for memory expansion, P-Code capabilities, a disk drive controler and the RS-232 interface. You can also add a modem, speech synthetiser, disk drive and matrix printer...<br><br> ... TI BASIC is built into the computer, but it can also handle TI Extended BASIC, UCSD Pascal, TI LOGO, TMS-9900 Assembly language and TI PILOT ... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert on the Peerless 150 terminal</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pong-story.com" target="_blank">www.pong-story.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Carefully, one last time... I compared everything and I offered myself a BBC" <br><br> Lucky guy, he must be rich at more than 6300fr the BBC... At the end of the text we can read : <br><br> "The price : 6300fr maximum. Of course it's not given. More expensive than some (but I had already eliminated them)." !! <br><br> At least they are honest.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://pcenginefx.com" target="_blank">PC-EngineFX.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 1</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1989</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special 520-STFM bundle advert.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There's no catch. We're giving you the Atari 520 STFM and £500 worth of great software titles for just £399.99.<br> The twenty-three super titles include some of the greatest games and three excellent programs which introduce you to the BASIC programming language, computer-created music and the more popular computer applications such as word processing and spreadsheets...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right arrow, advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Redesigned front panel. Totally synchronous logic design. Same switch and LED arrangement as original Altair 8800. New back.lit Duralith (laminated plastic and mylar, bonded to aluminum) dress panel with multi.color graphics. New longer, flat toggle switches. Five new functions stored on front panel PROM inc1uding: DISPLAY ACCUMULATOR (displays contents of accumulator), LOAD ACCUMULATOR (loads contents of the 8 data switches (A7.AO) into accumulator), OUTPUT ACCUMULATOR (Outputs contents of accumulator to I/O device addressed by the upper 8 address switches), INPUT ACCUMULATOR (inputs to the accumulator from the I/O device), and SLOW (causes program execution at a rate of about 5 cycles per second for program debugging). <br><br> Two, 34 conductor ribbon cable assemblies. Connects front panel board to front panel interface board. Eliminates need for complicated front panel/bus wiring. <br><br> New front panel interface board buffers all lines to and from 8800b bus. <br><br> Rugged, commercial grade Optima cabinet. <br><br> Full 18 slot motherboard. <br><br> New CPU board with 8080A microprocessor and Intel 8224 clock generator and 8216 bus drivers. Clock pulse widths and phasing as well as frequency are crystal controlled. Compatible with all current Altair 8800 software and hardware!. <br><br> New, heavy duty power supply: +8 volts at 18 amps, + 18 volts at 2 amps, -18 volts at 2 amps. 110 volt or 220 volt operation (50/60 Hz). Primary tapped for either high or low line operation.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to <a href="http://blogs.linux.ie/fuzzbucket/archives/p/7/more/1/c/1/Vintage-Sinclair-QL-catalogue" target="_blank">fuzzbucket</a> for this complete QL catalogue.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #5</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (MAR. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said<br><br><font color="#666666"> The electric typewriter's days are numbered. Because now there's a machine that put real wordprocessing power within everyone's reach.<br> The Amstrad PCW 8256 is a complete word-processor and a powerful computer in one unit.<br> And it's unbelievably low price includes a screen with built-in disc drive, keyboard, printer and word processing software...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - SYSTEM IN SPACE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Here comes Sirius 1 : the micro-computer which has an elephant memory"<br> ...<br> "A new era for computing"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The personal computer of Mr sales manager"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRIDGE COMPUTER VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In 1982, the <b>Bridge Computer Company</b> (Newton, MASS) sold a Z80 software developper system with the InterSystems mainframe, CP/M 2.2 operating system and various optional programming languages.The configuration was:<br><br> - 6 Mhz. Z80-B CPU with memory management<br> - 256 KB RAM expandable to 1 MB<br> - Two 8" or 5.25" F.D. drives, single or double sided<br> - Optional 5" or 8" hard disk, up to 40 MB<br> - Televideo serial video terminal. <br><br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Does this sound too good to be true? Just fill your tank with the BRIDGE 3C formula for SPEED and shift into 'overdrive' with your bridge 3C Compiler System. Leave the other behind, let us provide you with the fuel for higher productivity...</font> </blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: X68030 : 2 x 5.25'' disk-drivesX6030 Compact : 2 x 3.5'' disk-drives
computer.description:
The X68030 Pro was the successor of the X68000 XVI Compact. It was the last evolution of the X68 series.
It was followed by the X68030 Compact which used 3.5" floppy disks instead of the 5.25".
There were lots of hardware developments on this computer, in particular an accelerator card based on the Motorola 68040 or 68060.

emulator.description: X68000 emulator for linux and windows
emulator.name: Virtual X68000 Project

emulator.description: X68000 Emulator PPC is currently the only X68000 emulator available for the Macintosh
emulator.name: X68000 Emulator PPC

computer.media: X68030 : 2 x 5.25'' disk-drivesX6030 Compact : 2 x 3.5'' disk-drives
computer.name: X68030 / 68030 Compact
computer.ports: Joystick (2), Audio IN / OUT, TV Control, NTSC Video Image I/O, Expansion (2), External FDD, SCSI, RS232
computer.sound: FM Sound (Yamaha 2151 : 2 channels / 8 octaves stereo) + PCM (OKI MSM6258V : 4 bit mono)
